home.aboutMeParagraph:
Sophie Stupalo is a 3rd year biomedical engineering student at the University of Waterloo. She exhibits acute awareness of the existing and growing inequities deeply rooted in our current social constructs.  Sophie believes that these inequities must be addressed actively by developing and sharing technology that both meets the needs of today’s diverse and evolving society while sustainably addressing climate challenges.  She simply believes that inaction is socially inexcusable and morally unforgivable.

Change is coming, and Sophie is confident in her ability to lead the way.  She feels responsible and inspired to add value and social good through her work.  She spreads enthusiasm amongst her friends and colleagues that share common values, and warmly connects with individuals that differ.

Sophie is caring, productive, decisive, and a delightful team leader and contributor.  With almost a decade of work experience, Sophie has proven herself as a leader who exhibits focus, determination and sheer will to drive initiatives from start to finish.

Sophie is looking forward to developing biotechnology that is socially equitable and considerate of our shared environment.  Her interests are in design, medicine, and entrepreneurship.  She is ready, with a sustainable mindset and her attention to detail, to tackle the evolving challenges of global resource scarcity, climate change and sustainability.

Welcome, keep exploring, maybe you'll find something inspiring and if you have any questions please reach out.

experienceList.content:
GoFleet and Zenduit are telematic solutions providers focused on optimizing fleet management which service a variety of industries. As a product manager I was in charge of numerous projects over the course of my 4-month coop term. Namely, I was responsible for the complete ownership two software products, ZenduTimeCard and Support Ticket add-in, I designed and managed the implementation of a self-serve model for our ZenduWork software, I developed user journeys for a new marketplace application, and I worked one-on-one with designers and developers to create and deploy multiple new websites and landing pages.

ZenduTimeCard is a time-tracking software that harnesses location tracking to automatically log employees’ hours and can be easily integrated with existing company payroll systems to make payroll more efficient and less error prone for HR administrators. Support Ticket add-in provides a comprehensive dashboard where administrators can submit and monitor the status of their company’s service requests. “Complete ownership” of each product meant that I was responsible for identifying and logging bugs, working with users to determine pain points, designing new features to tackle those pain points, writing structured development tickets, managing the priority of tickets, and finally, creating written and video documentation to describe how to use the tool and its new features.

Designing the ZenduWork self-serve model involved creating a thorough user journey that described the steps a user would take to create an account, learn the main features of the tool, and begin using the tool to manage their fleet’s work orders. Next, I worked with a designer to create cohesive and intuitive screens for each step of the process, transcribed welcome emails and steps for the onboarding tutorial, and monitored the initial development of this project.

My main learning outcomes from this position were how to create effective user journeys, how to manage myself and projects using modular ToDo lists, and how to communicate the progress of different projects with stakeholders.

Christie is a global audio-visual solutions company whose goal is to inspire audiences through exceptional experiences powered by their AV solutions and display products. As an agile software developer, I contributed to both the Mystique and Mystique Design Web (MDW) products while participating in regular agile sprint related meetings.

The Mystique software is an automated camera-based alignment and recalibration solution that streamlines the installation, alignment, calibration, and maintenance processes of multi-projection systems.

MDW is a web application that allows users to simulate multi-projection setups and test the efficacy of the Mystique software prior to the final installation. My main term project involved developing the ability to simulate colour divergence and chromatic aberration within MDW. This full stack development used ReactJS to add UI inputs which allowed a user to select the translation, rotation, or scale of the red, green, or blue pixels of each projector. C++, CUDA, and OpenGL shaders were used to define the backend logic of each transformation and display where the transformed pixels would land on the screen.

In addition to my term project, I regularly completed bug fixes as they arose or were assigned to me.

The Department of Management Sciences at the University of Waterloo recognized the need for a replacement data visualization tool to aid with their accreditation processes. As a developer research assistant supervised by Dr. Mehrdad Pirnia, I developed an R Shiny web app which helped the department consolidate all of their student data while generating specific tables and graphs for their CEAB outcomes-based assessment report. The visualisation tool was deployed on a remote Shiny Server running an Ubuntu operating system with an ODBC connection to a central MySQL database. Although I worked independently on this project, I took an agile approach to the engineering design process which involved weekly follow up meetings with Dr. Pirnia (the primary user) to discuss new features or requirements.

Gumstix is an online marketplace for customizable embedded electronic hardware. During my term as a platform developer intern, I contributed to the development of hardware-specific embedded Linux distributions for custom PCB assemblies using Yocto. During the learning stage of my term, I had the task of diagnosing Gumstix images that were not executing properly by investigating the Linux file system and presenting possible solutions. This helped me to familiarize myself with the hardware I would continue to use throughout my term.

Later I was responsible for updating all of the Gumstix meta layers and Yocto manifest to be compatible with Dunfell (the latest release of Yocto). While completing this task I learned how to configure PCB assemblies by modifying Device Tree Source files using overlays and parameters (pin multiplexing) to change the physical behaviour of targeted GPIOs.

Near the end of my term I was tasked with enabling automatic detection and setup for two different Bluetooth/WiFi chip configurations. This involved writing Yocto recipes to install a module, initialisation tool, service, and udev rule file on the custom images. This was one of my most challenging work terms as I had to learn how to work with Linux, Yocto, and various hardware to be successful while working entirely remotely due to COVID-19. Despite the challenges, this term taught me resilience, resourcefulness, and when to ask for help.

Treetop Trekking Brampton is an aerial park in the Heart Lake Conservation Area. In the aerial guide role, I was responsible for conducting orientations, interacting with customers, supervising aerial park courses to ensure patron safety, conducting daily course and equipment safety inspections, and experiencing patience while working with large school and camp groups.

Throughout high school, I worked part-time as a lifeguard and swim instruct for the City of Brampton. Both roles required me to maintain all of the relevant physical and lifesaving qualifications. Teaching swimming lessons involved demonstrating and evaluating skills, communicating students’ progress with their parents/guardians, and most importantly keeping every student informed and safe at all times. On select weekends I also assisted with teaching advanced lifesaving courses including Bronze Cross and Standard First Aid.

Wet ‘n’ Wild Toronto is a waterpark and where I got my first paid job. As a lifeguard, I worked with various lifeguarding teams supervising swimmers. Due to the popular/busy nature of the park, I ended up leading 11 successful rescues and acted as a supporting guard during countless other rescues.

projectList.title: Lacrosse Club
projectList.subtitle: University Athletics Club
projectList.content:
My decision to study at the University of Waterloo (UW) was a difficult one as it meant I would have to give up playing the sport of lacrosse. Instead of giving up the sport I loved, I founded a women’s lacrosse club at my school with the goal of one day developing into a competitive OUA varsity team. This project began in the fall of 2019 and has since developed into a co-ed club.

During the summer prior to attending my first year I got started on this endeavor, collecting donated equipment, reaching out to UW athletics, advertising though the Ontario Lacrosse Association and navigating the club establishment process. In the fall I attended the Warriors Athletic Club fair to showcase our club and advertise our try-it sessions which proved to be a huge success.  By the end of our first term our club had 20 registered participants.  The restrictions due to the COVID pandemic made it more difficult for people to join our practices but participants’ continued engagement and interest have kept the club alive.

Not every sports team I have participated on in the past has been as welcoming as it should have been so when creating my club’s constitution, I made sure to focus on developing policies to foster a positive and friendly environment.  I also decided to continue running a club team even after a varsity team has been established so that other students who join the club can enjoy the same benefits in a less competitive and demanding environment. Our club is also working with the UW Alliance, and the Black Liberated Athletes Coalition to ensure we are taking all steps necessary to truly embrace diversity and welcome everyone who may be interested in playing lacrosse. Since our club was built on the values of equity and inclusiveness, we work hard to balance our membership fees so that it is not a limiting factor for who can play in our club while also maximizing our revenue so that we can provide a stick for any player that does not already have one.

Now I currently hold the position of President of the UW Field Lacrosse club team. In this role, I am responsible for chairing weekly executive meetings to plan future club initiatives as well as creating and executing 2 practice plans each week. One of the biggest challenges I’ve faced has been acquiring borrowed or cheap equipment since lacrosse is not a common sport. What I have learned is that good things come to those who seek them, and it was a matter of reaching out the right people to solve my problem. Not being afraid to ask for favors from the community has provided our club with over 60 sticks, 3 nets, and lots of lacrosse balls.

The success of the club so far has been extremely rewarding and I am excited at the prospect of reaching our club’s goal of becoming a competitive team prior to my graduation in 2024.

projectList.title: Woodworking
projectList.subtitle: Waterfall Coffee Table
projectList.content:
During my summer co-op term of 2022, I was fortunate to be living where I had access to a woodshop. Inspired by many of my boyfriend’s projects, I decided that I wanted to collaborate with him to create a waterfall coffee table. We had previously seen this type of table in a jewelry shop and thought this project would be a great use for our leftover live edge walnut board while expanding our woodworking skills.

We started by designing our table using pen and paper to make sure that using 18’’ hairpin legs would still leave enough material to have at least a 3’ table surface. Next, we measured 18’’ from one end of the plank and cut it on a 45-degree angle with a mitre saw to create the waterfall leg of the table. The type of cut was repeated twice on the remaining plank to create a mitre joint where the wood grain of the table surface seamlessly continued into the leg of the table. Once both planks were cut, we used walnut wood filler to fix any gouges and cracks in the wood. We then sanded each piece with 50, 100, 150, and 200 grit sandpaper to remove surface imperfections and make them smooth to the touch. Our next step involved gluing the two pieces together with wood glue. Although we had corner clamps, we decided not to use them since they would likely rip of the bark from the edges of the boards. Instead, we created a rig out of spare wood that allowed us to clamp the boards together at a 90-degree angle without damaging the bark. After the glue dried, we sanded each board again to remove any glue residue. We used tack cloths and pressurized air to remove all of the dust before applying multiple coats of polyurethane water-based wood finish to each surface and bark of the table. Once all the final coat of finish dried, we attached the hairpin legs and two L brackets to the underside of the table.

Seeing the finished product of this table was extremely rewarding and I felt I learned a number of new skills throughout the process.
